entry.title: How to plan the ultimate coastal Greece road trip
entry.summary:
Panagia Chapel sits on a small island off the coast of Parga. Take a gently paced coastal road trip from Kalamata in the southern Peloponnese to Parga in Epirus to experience ancient sites, fishing villages and beaches lapped by the Ionian Sea.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A slow road trip along mainland Greeceâ€™s coastline takes you from one idyllic site to another, from whitewashed villages tucked alongside sea fortresses to quiet beaches just a short drive from ancient temples. There are plenty of opportunities to stop off for a seafood lunch and a quick swim, and chances to end each day with a sundowner overlooking the sea.
Start in Kalamata in the southern Peloponnese, where Greece dips its toes into the gulf linking the Ionian â€¦

entry.title: Topic: Affirmative action in college admissions (DO NOT PUBLISH)
entry.summary: Printable PDF Background Affirmative action can be traced to the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s. It is an effort to increase opportunities for racial and ethnic groups that face barriers advancing in the workplace and other institutions, including higher education. In the 1960s, colleges and universities began to set up admissions policies that gave [â€¦] The post Topic: Affirmative action in college admissions (DO NOT PUBLISH) appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: There's a new clue to solve the universe's biggest mystery
entry.summary:
If you had asked me a year ago about the most likely ultimate fate of the universe, I would have been able to answer immediately. As a cosmologist, Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time thinking about the end of the universeâ€”I even wrote a book on the topic. We know the universe is expanding, and that expansion is speeding up. In the far distant future, this accelerating expansion will empty out the cosmos until thereâ€™s essentially nothing left. Stars burn out, matter decays, black holes evaporate, and eventually nothing is left but a few stray particles of light diffusing away the waste heat of all creation. This scenario is sometimes called the â€œheat deathâ€ or the â€œbig freezeâ€, and itâ€™s a straightforward consequence of our best working theory for how the universe behaves.
But if you asked me todâ€¦

entry.title: Why pho tastes different depending on where you are
entry.summary:
In the buzzing matrix of Hanoiâ€™s old quarter sits Phá»Ÿ ThÃ¬n, one of 700-or-so pho restaurants that speckle this thousand-year-old city. Phá»Ÿ ThÃ¬n is practically outfitted with stainless steel tables, embellished by jars and shakers, over wastebaskets for the innumerable spent lime rinds and napkins requisite for enjoying Vietnamâ€™s beloved national dish. Beneath the whirr of fans and clank of lids, diners pore over their bowls of phá»Ÿ bÃ² (beef pho), which owner Nguyá»…n Trá»ng ThÃ¬n has been serving here since 1979.â€¯Â
Nguyá»…n opened Phá»Ÿ ThÃ¬n in the scarce years following the Vietnam War, hoping it would always enable him to feed his newborn son. A fiercely proud Hanoian from a family that has resided in this very neighborhood for 10 generations, Nguyá»…n developed his pho recipe, slightly smoky â€¦

entry.title: How Scotland is reviving an ancient pagan fire ritual
entry.summary:
Each spring, on the night of April 30, thousands gather on Edinburghâ€™s Calton Hill to welcome the return of summerâ€”with fire. Performers dressed in dramatic costumes move through the crowd, reenacting ancient rituals to drums and chants echoing across the city.
The crowdâ€”locals and tourists alikeâ€”comes for the Beltane Fire Festival, Britainâ€™s largest modern celebration of an ancient that honors fire, fertility, and the changing season. Revived in 1988 by a group of artists and volunteers, the festival has grown into a high-energy spectacle rooted in tradition but shaped by modern values.
So how did a nearly forgotten pagan fire ritual become one of Scotlandâ€™s most iconic annual events?
Beltane (pronounced BEL-tayn) is one of eight seasonal festivals in the Celtic calendar,â€¦

entry.title: What to know about stage 0 cancerâ€”and why itâ€™s rarely diagnosed
entry.summary:
While most of us have heard of stage I, II, and III cancerâ€”and especially the grimmest stage IVâ€”many people don't know there's also an earlier stage of cancer known as stage 0.
Until recently, that included Tina Knowles, the mother of singer Beyonce, who revealed a breast cancer diagnosis in her new memoir. In anÂ interviewÂ about the importance of getting screened early and often for cancer she said, "I didn't know that there was a stage 0. I could have caught this at stage 0 if I had not missed my mammogram."Â Â
(When should you get screened for breast cancerâ€”and how often?)
Itâ€™s unsurprising that Knowles didnâ€™t know about stage 0 as it isnâ€™t as commonly diagnosed as the other stages of cancer. It also isnâ€™t detectable for many types of cancer and often goes by a different naâ€¦

entry.title: This ancient croc was bigger than most dinosaurs
entry.summary: The giant crocodilian Deinosuchus was a top predator in wetlands habitats of the late Cretaceous. Here Deinosuchus hatcheri, a species from a rock formation in what is now Utah, chows down on a duck-billed dinosaur called Rhinorex condrupus. The prehistoric crocodile relative may have tolerated both freshwater and saltwater habitats, allowing it to conquer North American coasts in the Cretaceous. Around 75 million years ago, North Americaâ€™s largest and most formidable carnivore was not a dinosaurâ€”but a croc. Deinosuchus, the â€œterrible crocodileâ€ in Greek, could reach more than 35 feet in length and weigh over five tons. Bite marks on bones leave no doubt that the immense reptile caught and ate dinosaurs. How Deinosuchus became such a large and widespread pâ€¦

entry.title: Heading to Rome? Here are 5 towns near the Eternal City you can't miss.
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting Rome should consider visiting nearby lesser-known towns like Tivoli to explore nature, art, and history without the crowds. Had enough of the crowds? Once youâ€™ve seen Rome, consider a day trip to these lesser known but no less beautiful towns for sunbathing, medieval charm, and fairy-tale gardens.
As one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world, Rome welcomes hordes of tourists every day. However, 2025 is the Holy Year of the Catholic Church, and the amalgamation ofÂ 35 million pilgrimsÂ visiting the Eternal City for the Jubilee might make your Roman holiday more hell than heaven if you donâ€™t plan ahead. Although the local administration made manyÂ infrastructure renovations, Rome will still be overpopulated â€“ not to mention plagued by price inflation fâ€¦

entry.title: A cozy travel blanket is the little luxury that packs a big punch
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
It may not seem like a necessity, but a comfy cozy travel blanket can make a big difference on trips.Â Â
â€œSome of us may sleep very well when we travel, while others may struggle,â€ says sleep expert Rebecca Robbins, an assistant professor in medicine at Harvard Medical School and an associate scientist at the Brigham and Womenâ€™s Hospital. â€œBringing elements that are cozy and comforting, such as a blanket, eye mask, or other elements, can remind you oâ€¦

entry.title: Why heart attacks are rising in young adults
entry.summary:
Despite declines among older adults, the proportion of heart attacks among younger adults is increasing across the globeâ€”an alarming trend that many doctors who spoke to National Geographic consider a public health emergency. (Young adults are loosely defined as those between 20 to 50 years old.)
Mounting evidence also shows that more young adults are experiencing all kinds of heart problems compared to decades past, and that worsening lifestyle habitsâ€”namely, poor diet and lack of exerciseâ€”are to blame. And some research suggests that COVID infections are adding insult to injury.
(It's not just heart attacks. Colon cancer is rising among young adults.)
Recent events have underscored these concerns. In 2024, a healthy 38-year-old made headlines after he had a heart attack anâ€¦

entry.title: Will a woman finally break the 4-minute mile?
entry.summary:
Eldoret, Kenyaâ€œWatch her,â€ says the man with the stopwatch, nodding toward the far end of the sun-cracked track. Itâ€™s a Saturday morning in March at the dilapidated stadium in the city of Eldoret, high above the Great Rift Valley in western Kenya. I follow the manâ€™s gaze to where the greatest middle-distance runner of all time rounds the last turn, training for the impossible.Â Â
Itâ€™s hard to gauge the speed of 31-year-old Faith Kipyegon. She is too smooth. Though she runs nearly at a sprint, her arms and legs slide forward and back with a liquid ease. Her face shows so little strain she might be a jogger out for a brisk trot around Central Park. Only her eyes betray her effort. They seem not to notice the spalling concrete of the never finished stadium, the weeds that grow in its granâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 167 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 7 to April 13, 2025. A total of 3,589 panelists responded out of 4,036 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research Analyst Shanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial Nida Asheer, Senior [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Economic ratings and concerns
entry.summary: About a quarter (23%) of Americans say the economy is in excellent or good shape, and 45% expect conditions to be worse a year from now. The post 4. Economic ratings and concerns appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Views of Congress, parties and courts
entry.summary: Over nine-in-ten Americans say it's important that federal judges are fair and impartial in their rulings, but far fewer have confidence they actually are. The post 5. Views of Congress, parties and courts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Tariffs, DEI and cuts to government: Views of Trumpâ€™s key actions
entry.summary: More Americans disapprove than approve of the Trump administration's government cuts, tariffs increases and ending of federal DEI policies. The post 3. Tariffs, DEI and cuts to government: Views of Trumpâ€™s key actions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of how the Trump administration governs
entry.summary: About half of Americans say Trump is doing to much by executive order, and most say his administration must follow federal court rulings. The post 2. Views of how the Trump administration governs appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Evaluations of Trump: Job approval and confidence on issues
entry.summary: Trump's job approval is down since February, especially among his less strong supporters and 2024 nonvoters. And fewer than half of Americans have confidence in Trump to handle most issues. The post 1. Evaluations of Trump: Job approval and confidence on issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Trumpâ€™s Job Rating Drops, Key Policies Draw Majority Disapproval as He Nears 100 Days
entry.summary: Trump's approval rating stands at 40%, and Americans mostly disapprove of his tariffs and government cuts. The post Trumpâ€™s Job Rating Drops, Key Policies Draw Majority Disapproval as He Nears 100 Days appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Largely eradicated diseases at risk of returning due to budget cuts
entry.summary: Vaccines have saved around 150 million lives over the past 50 years, but that progress is now under threat.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Health, education, opportunity at stake, amid stubborn digital gender divide
entry.summary: As transformative technologies such as Artificial Intelligence continue to reshape the global economy, millions of women and girls remain excluded from the digital world â€“ denied not only access to opportunity, but also the chance to shape their own futures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sexual violence systematically used as a weapon of war in the DR Congo
entry.summary: The ongoing conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to have devastating consequences, particularly for women and children, who face an increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sewage, trash and disease overwhelm displaced communities in Gaza
entry.summary: Amid sweltering heat, raw sewage and overflowing trash, displaced families in southern Gaza are facing an escalating public health crisis as aid remains blocked and medical supplies dwindle.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AI lightens the workload â€“ but risks remain, labour agency warns
entry.summary: Artificial intelligence, robotics, and digitalization are rapidly reshaping how we work â€“ but theyâ€™re a source of unexpected risks too.

entry.title: World leaders rally for â€˜full-speedâ€™ climate action ahead of COP30
entry.summary: At a high stakes virtual summit on Wednesday, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres and Brazilian President Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva brought together 17 national leaders from major economies and climate-vulnerable countries. The goal was to accelerate global climate ambition ahead of COP30, which will be hosted in Brazil.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stopping child marriage is key to curbing deadly teen pregnancies: WHO
entry.summary: Teenage pregnancy remains the leading cause of death for girls aged 15 to 19, which countries could help prevent by allowing them to remain in school and ending child marriage, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Inside the Arizona city that's America's final frontier
entry.summary:
The Mission San Xavier del Bac dates back to the 1700s and depicts Tucson's Spanish-filled roots. The city of Tucson, Arizona, sits on Americaâ€™s southern border, surrounded by the cactus-strewn landscapes of the Sonoran Desert. Its present-day creativity draws on its Native American and Mexican roots, Spanish colonial heritage and Wild West frontier days.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). The desert is the greenest on the planet and sustains two of Arizonaâ€™s three wine regions. One, Sonoita, is home to the Los Milics Vineyards winery. The city, meanwhile, is a canvas for countless street artists, including London-based Fin DAC, whose mural Vergiss adorns the side of Charro Steak & Del Rey restaurant. The view through the saguaâ€¦

entry.title: The blackout that nearly broke NYCâ€”and the logo that saved it
entry.summary:
During the 1977 blackout, fires broke out across New York City, exposing the depths of its financial and social crisis. In the aftermath, a simple logo helped reshape the cityâ€™s image. In 1977, with dozens of fires set daily and tourism in freefall, New York hired an artist to save the city. His infamous sketch in the back of a yellow cab became the most imitated logo in historyâ€”and cities are still copying it today.
In the summer of 1977, New York City was burning. A 25-hour blackout, triggered by lightning striking key transmission lines, led to widespread looting, riots, and more than a thousand fires.
That night alone, the fire department battled blazes across Harlem, Brooklyn, and the South Bronx, a shocking surge in a city already averaging four dozen fires a day. New Yoâ€¦

entry.title: Escape the crowds at the lower 48â€™s most remote national park
entry.summary:
At a time when record crowds are seeing visitors to some U.S. national parks asked to pre-book access, Isle Royale National Park, an archipelago of around 400 islands on western Lake Superior, is the very definition of off the beaten track.
Its main island is about 50 miles long and nine miles wideâ€”19 times the size of Manhattanâ€”and sees less than one percent of the average number of visitors to Yosemite National Park when it opens to the public on around April 15 every year.
As the least-visited national park in the continental U.S., Isle Royale National Park is only reachable by ferry, private boat or seaplane from mainland Michigan and Minnesota.
Itâ€™s a place where the only vehicles are canoes and kayaks, and moose, wolves, beavers and smaller animals are the sole year-roâ€¦

entry.title: How ancient trash is protecting these coastal islands today
entry.summary:
On the barrier islands off the coast of Georgia,Â around 585 square miles of salt marshes lie next to forests so dense with hardwoods and Spanish moss that sunshine can only filter through in slender rays.
â€œTheyâ€™re almost otherworldly,â€ says Jacob Holland-Lulewicz, an archaeologist at Pennsylvania State University. To visitors, these islands can feel untouched.
Yet, recent research by Holland-Lulewicz and his colleagues shows how humans have significantly altered these barrier islands over millennia by discardingÂ millions of oyster shells, unintentionally creating deposits so substantial they now protect portions of the islands from today's rising sea levels.
â€œThese ecosystems that we all enjoy and that we want to preserve are actually the result of thousands of years of indiâ€¦

entry.title: We thought Andean bears were muteâ€”until they were heard mating
entry.summary:
New discoveries about the Andean bear language show that the species makes five distinct sounds during mating. Researchers have captured footage of these bears making a wide range of vocalizations during their most intimate momentsâ€”the first time sounds of this kind have been documented in any bear species.
Until recently, the Andean bearâ€”the only species of bear in South America, easily recognized by the light-colored markings that frame its face like glassesâ€”was thought to be almost mute; there were only a few documented cases of vocal exchanges between mothers and cubs in captivity. But recently, deep in the Andes, camera traps captured something unexpected: During mating, this elusive creature becomes surprisingly expressive. It moans, growls, and purrs.
With this new infoâ€¦

entry.title: Portable photo printers are one of our favorite travel gadgets
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Digital photos may be convenient for travel, but thereâ€™s something special about holding a printed picture. Portable photo printers let you turn your favorite snapshots into instant keepsakes, no matter where you are.Â Â
â€œIâ€™ve been journaling my whole life but started taking it more seriously in 2020 as a way to relive my adventures, and since then, I incorporate different creative elements into my journaling, including photography,â€ says Ayusha Ayaâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The analysis in this report is based on a self-administered web survey conducted from Sept. 18 to Oct. 10, 2024, among a sample of 1,391 dyads, with each dyad (or pair) comprised of one U.S. teen ages 13 to 17 and one parent per teen. The margin of sampling error for the full sample of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Teens, Social Media and Mental Health
entry.summary: Parents are more worried than teens about teen mental health. Both groups â€“ especially parents â€“ partly blame social media. But teens also see benefits. The post Teens, Social Media and Mental Health appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: These are the best dishes to try in Kuala Lumpur
entry.summary:
The ebi katsu sando at Reka Bar consists of succulent prawn katsu between a soft, vibrant ube milk loaf. Innovative chefs are mixing traditional ingredients with modern techniques in Malaysia's capital.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).Â Â
The dining scene in Kuala Lumpur has long reflected Malaysiaâ€™s rich cultural tapestry, with traditional Malay, Chinese and Indian cuisines as staples. And now, the city is embracing culinary innovation, too. From elevated street food to avant-garde fine dining, chefs are pushing boundaries with fusion dishes and unique ingredients. Here are the best places to experience the Malaysian capitalâ€™s ever-evolving food landscape.
This dish epitomises chef Darren Teohâ€™s commitment to celebrating local, indigenâ€¦

entry.title: Lentils and peas are overlooked protein powerhouses
entry.summary:
Beans hog the nutritional spotlight in the kitchen and on TikTok, but their fellow legumes lentils and peas pack high nutritional punches, too. These foods are so full of protein, fiber, and antioxidants that the American diet should be brimming with them, according to a recent report by the U.S. governmentâ€™s 2025 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee.
Various legumes are staples in Indian, Middle Eastern, and other cuisines but rare in classic American fare. â€œIt is embarrassing how few legumes people eat in the U.S.,â€ says Christopher Gardner, a nutrition scientist at Stanford University who helped author the new report. Even when people do eat them, he says, they lean towards the categoryâ€™s most prominent member, beans.Â
(Black beans, pinto, and cannellini are also nutritionallâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Sharktopusâ€™ isn't aloneâ€”these animals hitchhike on other animals.
entry.summary: A classic example of phoresy, the remora uses a modified fin that latches onto larger animals like a suction cup. Here three remoras (Remora brachyptera) ride a Chilean devil ray (Mobula tarapacana) off the coast of Santa Maria Island, Azores.  Cockroaches that catch a ride on ants. Grasshoppers that climb aboard sheep. Hitchhiking animals are more common than you think. Spend enough time in nature, and you will see some weird stuffâ€”from orcas swimming around wearing salmon like hats to wombats pooping cubes. But when Rochelle Constantine saw a nine-foot-long mako shark jet past her research vessel in the Hauraki Gulf off New Zealand with a huge, orange octopus globbed onto its head, she knew she was witnessing something new.Â  â€œIt was jusâ€¦

entry.title: 10 eclectic, must-see museums in San Diego
entry.summary:
A visitor passes through the "Light Floor" art installation at the WNDR Museum in San Diego. To get a feel for the soul of San Diego, stop by these innovative museums found in Balboa Park and along the scenic coastline.
San Diegoâ€™s epicenter for arts and culture is Balboa Park. This 1,200-acre urban oasis is home to 18 museums (and dozens of gardens, attractions, and fun venues). Visit the traditional institutions hereâ€”or swing over to theÂ recently addedÂ Comic-Con Museum.Â Â Â Â Â Â
In case you didnâ€™t know, Balboa Park shares a zip code with downtown San Diego, and the cityâ€™s urban core has its own set of eclectic offerings, like the nauticalÂ USS Midway MuseumÂ andÂ the Maritime Museum. With so many museums in the city, museophiles can pare down their options with this helpful list oâ€¦

entry.title: We planned the perfect day in San Diego for 3 types of travelers
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting San Diego can plan the perfect day trip to explore the city with three itineraries designed for families, adventurers, and culture enthusiasts. San Diego is known as the heart of SoCal surf culture, but there's more to this city than just beaches and sunny weather. Hereâ€™s how to explore the cityâ€™s intriguing history, impressive museums and vibrant neighborhoods.
While Spanish explorer Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo failed to find an all-water routeâ€”the mythical â€œStrait of Anianâ€â€”across North America in 1542, he did discover San Diego Bay, which he remarked was â€œa very good port.â€ The Indigenous Kumeyaay people had already lived there for thousands of years. Cabrillo still claimed the land for Spain, beginning a tumultuous period where San Diego would be under Spanish, tâ€¦

entry.title: The brain has a secret survival trick to endure a marathon
entry.summary:
A marathon taxes more than just musclesâ€”it pushes the brain to its metabolic limits. New research shows that during extreme endurance events, the brain may burn its own fat for fuel, revealing just how adaptableâ€”and surprisingâ€”the mind can be. A study of long-distance runners shows the brainâ€™s remarkable ability to adaptâ€”by burning its own fat.
Carlos Matute wasnâ€™t looking for a scientific breakthrough when he laced up his shoes for a long run. But as the miles ticked by, theÂ neuroscientistÂ from the University of the Basque Country found himself chasing a persistent question: â€œHow do we make it to the finish line, being conscious, after having our energy stores depleted?â€Â
That curiosity led to a surprising possible answer. InÂ a recent studyÂ inÂ Nature Metabolism, Matute found â€¦

entry.title: Here are 9 top-notch sun hats for travelers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Every traveler knows sunscreen is essential for any trip. But experts also recommend supplementing lotions and creams with a good sun hat.Â
The Skin Cancer Foundation says the overwhelming majority of skin cancers are caused by cells that first appear on the head and neck and recommends hats for extra protection. The best sun hats have wide brims, flaps to protect the ears and neck (especially for outdoor activities), tight weaving to block rays, aâ€¦

entry.title: Avoid crowds at the 10 least-visited U.S. national parks
entry.summary:
A camper gazes at the central Brooks Mountain Range, which includes East and West Maiden Peaks, Camel Peak, and Arrigetch Peaksâ€”all found within the Alaska's Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve. Get off the beaten path at these under-the-radar wilderness areas.
Since its founding on August 25, 1916, the U.S. National Park Service has assembled 419 protected units, of which 62 hold the â€œnational parkâ€ designation. To visit all 63 of these treasures one would need to travel to 29 states and two U.S. territories.
But with so many national parks to visit, there are trails, craters, and lakeshores that can be explored responsibly and without crowds. How remote and uncrowded are these parks? Katmai National Parkâ€™s Aniakchak caldera is so remote that many park rangers haveâ€¦

entry.title: How to eat your way through San Diego like a local
entry.summary:
Mexican food and seafood are the obvious choices when visitingÂ San Diego. The culinary scene capitalizes on year-round perfect weather with rooftop terraces and oceanfront dining views. But the diversity of food options doesnâ€™t stop at tacos.
Â One neighborhood honors its historical heritage with authentic Italian restaurants, while another dedicates itself to representing the many cultures and flavors of Asian cuisine. Local craft beer is omnipresent, too. At local farmersâ€™ markets and restaurants, seasonal ingredients are showcased and usually plucked straight from one of the countyâ€™s 5,000 farms during peak ripeness.
Travelers looking to whet their palate with the best food in Southern California should fill their itinerary with these essential dishes and culinary experiences fâ€¦

entry.title: How a new pope is elected
entry.summary:
With the death of Pope Francis at the age of 88, the world will now turn to a pressing question: Who will be the next popeâ€”and how will he be elected?
After Pope Benedict XVIâ€™s resignation in 2013, it took two long weeks for the Catholic faithful to find out who would be their next representative of God on Earth.
Crowds in Saint Peter's Square at the Vatican let out a cheer as the white smoke from burned ballots signified a successful vote among the members of the College of Cardinals.Â It was the final act that sealed the intricate papal selection process that allegedly dates back to the time of Jesus Christ.
Hereâ€™s a closer look at the real story behind one of the Vaticanâ€™s most mysterious and time-honored processes.
The pope was originally the bishop of Rome, a â€¦

entry.title: Pope Francis dies at 88
entry.summary:
Pope Francis passed away at the Vatican on April 21, after leading the Catholic faithful since March 2013. His election as pope was characterized by firsts: He was the first man from outside of Europe to become pope in more than 1,200 years, the first supreme pontiff from South America, and the first member of the Jesuits to preside as bishop of Rome.
As head of the Holy See, Francis broke much new ground, and his leadership represented a significant shift in the office itself, focusing on bridging the widening gap between the elite administration of the Catholic Church and its flock. He also pioneered new approaches to long-held Catholic traditions and practices.
(Take a close look at Pope Francis's first visit to the United States.)
Francisâ€™s upbringing, training, anâ€¦

entry.title: An intimate look at Pope Francis's life at the Vatican
entry.summary:
Each morning Pope Francis awoke before dawn in his modest accommodation at Casa Santa Marta, the Vatican guestÂ­house. As day broke, Pope Francis prayed and meditated before delivering a homily at morning Mass.
By midday the pope had undertaken any number of duties, preferring to manage his schedule personally. Phone calls to colleagues and friends, meetings, and other appointments preceded lunch, after which he took a siesta.
His afternoons were often spent visiting prisons and juvenile detention centers, consulting with ambassaÂ­dors to the papacy, or making appointments. Once a week he received a soccer update from a member of the Swiss Guard, a necessity since the pope stopped watching television in 1990. Though Pope Francis may have given up television, he was an active lover of the arts. He enjoyed opera, classical music, and baroque artwork, and he identified Federico Fellini's La StradaÂ as his favorite film.
A few times a month, the pope led Papal Mass and hosted regular audiences in St. Peterâ€™s Square or the Basilica (and sometimes both on busy days), which allowed tens of thousands of people to be in the popeâ€™s presence. Often these individuals were from all over the world and wept and cheered when they caught a glimpse of the head of the Roman Catholic Church.
His evening meal was again taken among his fellow residents at the Casa Santa Marta. True to form, he never dined alone. Once back in his austere domicile, Pope Francis ended his day as it beganâ€”quietly. Each night, the pontiff read before drifting off to sleep.

entry.title: See how Pope Francis ushered in a new era for the Catholic Church
entry.summary:
Pope Francis always had an eye on the future. From the outset he recognized the need for a shift within the Catholic Church, which had lost the trust of many in recent years. His calls for change could be inspiring to many yet divisive to others as he ushered in transformational ideologies and a less formal period for the papacy.
As formality was thrust aside, older Catholic traditions were also reevaluated. In 2013, Francis named numerous women to roles high within the Vatican administration. When asked about the sexual preferences of priests, the pope replied, â€œIf someone is gay and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?â€ Pope Francis gave traditionalists within the Catholic Church pause, but subsequent statements in support of same-sex civil unions and about the â€œunjustâ€ criminalization of homosexuality attested to Francisâ€™s vision for the future of the church.Â
Francis also challenged the status quo by encouraging that the clergy make a place within the church for divorced and remarried Catholics. He urged them to â€œoffer understanding, comfort and acceptanceâ€ to single mothers, â€œrather than imposing straightaway a set of rules that only lead people to feel judged and abandoned.â€Â
In accordance with Pope Francisâ€™s hope for global harmony and cooperation, he issued a call to action for all Catholics to protect the planetâ€”â€œGodâ€™s creationâ€â€”in the face of environmental crises. And despite referring to himself as a â€œdinosaurâ€ when it came to computers, Pope Francis broke ground for the papacy by taking part in numerous online events, launching the Vatican into the digital age and connecting with millions of his flock.

entry.title: The last letter
entry.summary: Condemned to death by firing squad, French resistance fighters put pen to paper. Their dying words can teach us how to live - by Daniel R Brunstetter Read at Aeon

entry.title: Try this Norwegian Arctic lodge for an intro to pack-rafting
entry.summary:
Raft and hike through Norway's Alta Canyon beneath the midnight sun. On a trip to Norway's Alta, get an off-the-radar taste of the wild with river-rafting and hiking beneath the midnight sun.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
At 70 degrees north, where Norwayâ€™s coast frays into fjords, islands and skerries, Alta is a true blast of the Arctic. A two-hour flight from Oslo, one of the worldâ€™s most northerly towns takes â€˜wildâ€™ to a new level. Here, the Northern Lights rave above snowy fells all winter long, while the midnight sun burns in summer. Porpoises, dolphins and whales splash in frigid waters and the indigenous SÃ¡mi people herd reindeer on the stark tundra. And whether youâ€™re fishing the fjord for enormous king crab, listening to the crackâ€¦

entry.title: Best of Bohemiaâ€”discover 5 unmissable day trips from Prague
entry.summary:
Wrapped around Prague like an elegant scarf, Central Bohemia is a region rich in ancient history and natural beauty. Once at the heart of the Holy Roman Empire and the Habsburg realm, its storied past is evidenced at every turn by a parade of picture-perfect castles and cathedrals. Perhaps more surprising â€” considering the regionâ€™s proximity to the Czech capital â€” is the abundance of unspoilt nature, from forest-fringed rivers and natural springs, to yawning limestone caves and grand canyons. Here are five excellent reasons to add Central Bohemia to your next Czech adventure.
Macabre Sedlec Ossuary is probably Central Bohemiaâ€™s most photographed sight (though this has been restricted in recent years). From the outside, it looks like an unremarkable Catholic chapel, but step across tâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Dresden, Germany
entry.summary:
Before its destruction in the Second World War, Dresden was so famed for its beautiful baroque architecture that it was known as 'Florence on the Elbe'. Saxon puppetry, galleries and gardens: here's how to make the most of a short break in this German city.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Dresden's mural-adorned courtyards, modern artworks and yellow trams combine to make it an enigmatic city break destination. The Saxon capital offers laidback restaurants, riverside cafes and buzzing nightlife districts, all set in the shadows of its stately baroque buildings.
Beat the crowds and tick off one of Dresdenâ€™s biggest draws early, admiring the colonnaded courtyards, galleries and gardens of the Zwinger Palace, a masterpiece of baroque archâ€¦

entry.title: 6 hikes to try in the Rocky Mountains
entry.summary:
The 50 parking spots in the Emerald Lake lot tend to fill before 9am, so arrive early or park on the nearby Emerald Lake Road and walk to the lake. Explore trails in British Columbia that criss-cross Canadaâ€™s most spectacular mountain range â€” whatever your level of experience and fitness.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Imagine a quintessentially Canadian landscape and youâ€™re probably picturing the Rockies. These jagged peaks stretch 3,000 miles across the continent of North America, but some of the most soul-stirring sections straddle the border of British Columbia and Alberta. Whether you plan on a peaceful meander around a glacial lake or an expedition across dramatic mountain ridges, thereâ€™s a trail for every explorer. Nature-lovers willâ€¦

entry.title: Is this the most thrilling way to experience a Canadian river?
entry.summary:
To see the salmon in abundance, itâ€™s far better to don a wetsuit and float down the shallow Campbell River from late July to September, when the salmon run is taking place. Home to one of the world's greatest salmon migrations, Campbell River lives up to its title as the 'Salmon Capital of the World', offering travellers the rare chance to snorkel among thousands of chinook, chum and coho.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bald eagles circle overhead, black bears patrol the forested riverbank and harbour seals frolic in pools near the estuary mouth. Imagine youâ€™re immersed in a fast-flowing river, face down with a mask and snorkel, observing one of natureâ€™s greatest spectacles: a chaotic maelstrom of fish racing towards you, all possessed witâ€¦

entry.title: Is there really alien life on this exoplanet? We asked 10 experts.
entry.summary:
An illustration shows what exoplanet K2-18b might look like based on data from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. K2-18b is 8.6 times as massive as Earth, orbits the cool dwarf star K2-18 in the habitable zone and lies 120 light-years from Earth. A new study suggests it may have a molecule called dimethyl sulfide (DMS) in its atmosphere A team of astronomers claims to have sniffed out a â€œbiosignatureâ€ in the atmosphere of a distant planet called K2-18b. But not everyone agrees that it signals life.
In 2020, scientists claimed to have found a sign of life on Venus: hints of a stinky gas called phosphine thatâ€™s made by microbes on Earth. The claim was swiftly challenged and, years later, is still mired in controversy. Now, another stinky gas has sparked its own alien life debateâ€”thisâ€¦

entry.title: Rare, 1,600-year-old child remains found at a Maya altar
entry.summary:
Archaeologists excavating the ruins of the Maya city of Tikal have unearthed a 1,600-year-old altar likely used for human sacrifices, surrounded by the bones of children.
The grim discovery adds weight to the idea that Tikal was ruled at this time by overlords from the non-Maya city of Teotihuacan, more than 600 miles west in whatâ€™s now Mexico; and some of the sacrifices may have been efforts to ensure Teotihuacanâ€™s power over the local people.
â€œThe local dynasty, which was Maya, was allowed to continue, but under the heel of a foreign group,â€ says Brown University archaeologist Stephen Houston. In a new study in the journal Antiquity, Houston and his colleagues describe the altar and human remains unearthed from the ruins in whatâ€™s now Guatemala. The researchers think the altar â€¦

entry.title: What archaeology canâ€”and canâ€™tâ€”tell us about Jesusâ€™ crucifixion
entry.summary:
Visitors flock to the renovated Edicule in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem's old city. From the location of the â€œplace of skullsâ€ to ancient Jewish burial rites, hereâ€™s what archaeologists doâ€”and donâ€™tâ€”know about the truth behind the Easter story.
The death and resurrection of Jesus is the most famous underdog story in history. A low-status artisan from Galilee challenged the authorities of his time and ended up dying a brutal and horrifying death. But only a few days later, the Bible says, he was vindicated and resurrected from the dead. The story inspires billions of Christians around the world, but how much hard evidence is there for the historical events that started a global religion?
From a historical perspective, the Easter story is tremendously well attesâ€¦

entry.title: A first-timerâ€™s guide to Kaunas, Lithuaniaâ€™s eternal city
entry.summary:
Kaunas has had numerous rulers over time, from the Teutonic Knights to the Russian Empire. Nonetheless, throughout the years, Lithuaniaâ€™s second city (the fourth-largest in the Baltic states) has maintained its identity as a centre of culture and academia. Situated 62 miles west of Vilnius, Kaunasâ€™ architecture hints at the cityâ€™s great historical depth â€” from the gothic spires of its medieval Senamiestis (Old Town) to its angular art deco apartment buildings and ultra-modern additions such as the new Science Island. Hereâ€™s how to experience it all in a weekend.
Get ahead of the summer crowds by visiting Kaunas in spring, when the Sakura Park cherry blossoms on Nemunas Island are in bloom. Cultural season kicks off in April with the Kaunas Jazz Festival. In late May, the city celebrâ€¦

entry.title: Myanmar: Thousands remain in crisis weeks after deadly earthquakes
entry.summary: Thousands of families in Myanmar remain without shelter, water, or medical care three weeks after deadly earthquakes struck the country, as frequent aftershocks compound the suffering of communities already battered by conflict and poverty.

entry.title: Why Greeceâ€™s Zagori is a hikerâ€™s dream
entry.summary:
The Vikos Gorge trail in northwest Greece is 20 miles long, with the Voidomatis River forming a lake between the villages of Monodendri and Vikos. The footpaths that link the isolated mountain settlements of Zagori offer some of the most spectacular hiking in the whole of Greece.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greeks donâ€™t hike. Youâ€™ll hear this everywhere you go in Greece â€” usually from the locals themselves. They canâ€™t see the point, apparently; uses up too much beach time.
If thatâ€™s the case then no one told Anna Diamantopoulou and her jovial group of trekking pole-wielding beginners. I encounter them on the steep stone path that snakes down into Vikos Gorge from the village of Monodendri. Theyâ€™re audible long before theyâ€™re visible,â€¦

entry.title: 7 compact and powerful travel routers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Staying connected while traveling is important whether you need to work, want to stream your favorite shows, or just stay in touch with loved ones. However, public Wi-Fi can be unreliable and insecure, and international roaming fees can add up quickly. A travel router can solve these issues by offering secure, fast, and reliable internet access wherever you go.Â Â
â€œUltimately, the big benefit to travel routers is simplifying your connections,â€ says Sâ€¦

entry.title: How junk food outsmarts our brainsâ€”by hiding in our memories
entry.summary:
Cravings may feel impulsive, but new research suggests theyâ€™re often rooted in memory. Scientists have found that the brain encodes high-calorie foods in a way that can quietly influence what we eatâ€”even when weâ€™re not hungry. New research reveals that memories of fatty and sugary foods are encoded in the hippocampus, helping explain why some cravings feel impossible to resist.
The next time you remember a chocolate bar in a desk drawer, your brain might not just be recalling itâ€”it could be actively pushing you to seek it out.
A recent study published in Nature Metabolism suggests that specific neurons in the hippocampus log the sensory and emotional details of calorie-rich food. In mice, these neurons triggered cravings, leading to overeatingâ€”even when the animals werenâ€™t hunâ€¦

entry.title: Banff is stunningâ€”and crowded. Here are 7 alternatives
entry.summary:
A mountain climberâ€”perched on Bugaboo Spire in Bugaboo National Parkâ€”looks out at the sun with the Purcell Mountain Range in the background. From the aurora-lit skies of Canadaâ€™s newest dark sky park to the tiny railway town near one of Canadaâ€™s tallest waterfalls, these under-the-radar spots offer plenty of room to roam.
Youâ€™ve seen the social media posts: the towering and rugged peaks, the glossy, glacial lakes, and the lumbering bears disappearing into thick forests. This is Banff National Park, one of the most beautifulâ€”and famousâ€”places on Earth.Â
According to Banff and Lake Louise Tourism, nearly four million people visited Banff in 2024 alone, andÂ overtourism is a growing concern for Parks Canada. So, right now, itâ€™s an opportune time for travelersÂ to explore alternativâ€¦

entry.title: American Crying
entry.summary: People cry for different reasons and some tend to cry more than others. What makes people cry the most? Tags: crying

entry.title: 7 of the worldâ€™s quirkiest coastal celebrations
entry.summary:
Songkran, or Thailand's Buddhist New Year, is a celebration to cleanse and rejuvenate for the year ahead. On the streets, traditions take on a playful tone, in the form of an almighty water fight. From epic water fights and night-long cave raves to extravagant fruit-laden parades, these kooky events all make the most of the coast.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s no better way to tap into the soul of a destination than by diving headfirst into a local festival, when communities come alive in the most joyous ways â€” be it dancing, feasting or honouring a time-old tradition. Throw in a coastline, and the magic multiplies: the tang of salt in the air, the lure of the dayâ€™s catch and a backdrop of shifting seascapes all heighten the atmospâ€¦

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring Europe's mighty Danube River
entry.summary:
Danube is a popular river cruising destination in Europe. Saxon puppetry, galleries and gardens: here's how to make the most of a short break in this German city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Snaking almost 1,800 miles from its source in Germanyâ€™s Black Forest to the Black Sea in Romania, the Danube is best explored slowly. Cruises, the most popular option, provide up-close encounters with the river, allowing you to see plenty in just a week or two. They donâ€™t have to be obvious, with some cracking off-beat options taking you east and into the wilds of the Lower Danube. For an adventure at your own pace, consider hiking on a network of well-developed, marked trails or cycling the long-distance Danube Cycle Path, which largely shadows the râ€¦

entry.title: The worldâ€™s rarest penguins donâ€™t avoid heatâ€”they embrace it
entry.summary:
GalÃ¡pagos penguins populate Isabela Island, where they are joined by marine iguanas. Both animals occupy fissures in the coastlineâ€™s volcanic rock and forage in the ocean. These birds have evolved to withstand the equatorial sun and shelter in volcanic rocks along a subtropical coastline. After 50 years, biologist Dee Boersma continues to learn new things about the species.
Roughly 600 milesÂ off the coast of mainland Ecuador, conservation biologist Dee Boersma cruised in an inflatable Zodiac through the blue waters surrounding BartolomÃ© Island, a small part of the Pacific Ocean archipelago known as the GalÃ¡pagos Islands. She was joined by several other scientists, all of whom scanned the shoreline for an elusive black-and-white seabird. Standing about a foot and a half tall, GalÃ¡paâ€¦

entry.title: How global warming is disrupting life on Earth
entry.summary:
People view artist Luke Jerram's 'Floating Earth' at an urban lake in Wigan, England. The sculpture brought attention to global warming, the worldwide rise in temperature that's causing major climatic changes.  A warmer planet doesnâ€™t just raise temperatures. From wildfires to floods, here's how the climate is changing.
Since the Industrial Revolutionâ€”an event made possible by the use of fossil fuels in everything from power plants to transportationâ€”Earth has gotten hotter.
2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year Earth's temperature surpassed 1.5Â°C (2.7Â°F).
The past 10 years have been the 10 hottest years on record, and a reconstruction of Earth's average temperature over the past 485 million years showed that when the planet warms, catastrophic weatheâ€¦

entry.title: How Antarcticaâ€™s penguins became natureâ€™s daredevils
entry.summary:
Hundreds of emperor juveniles survived jumping into the sea from a 50-foot ice shelf last year. The impact may have been minimized by their small size, plentiful feathers on their belly, and strong breast muscles. From diving off cliffs to starving for months, emperor penguins are continuing to surprise scientists with their ability to adapt to one of the worldâ€™s most extreme environments.
â€œOh my god,Â this thingâ€™s going to die.â€ That was the thought running through the mind of wildlife filmmaker Bertie Gregory when he saw the first juvenile emperor penguin jump off a 50-foot cliff. The bird plummeted downward, splashing into the frigid Southern Ocean. After a few suspenseful seconds, it bobbed to the surface and then swam off toward the horizon. The National Geographic Explorer couâ€¦

entry.title: What â€˜trash heapâ€™ penguins can teach us about survival
entry.summary:
Chinstrap and gentoo penguins, shown here near Danco Island in Antarctica, regularly plunge to depths of over 100 feet on foraging runs. For more than 60 million years, penguins of all kindsâ€”including the opportunistic Magellanic penguinâ€”have been driven by an evolutionary urge to reach beyond their boundaries. Today, many are surfacing in the most unlikely places.
When Pablo â€œPopiâ€Â Borboroglu first visited a remote stretch of shoreline along the eastern coast of Patagonia, in 2008, the National Geographic Explorer was surprised to find penguins making a home there. The Argentine biologist was responding to a call from a nearby rancher who had seen several of the flightless birds on his property. When he arrived, Borboroglu found trash, broken glass, abandoned cars, and burned-out â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 166 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from March 24 to March 30, 2025. A total of 3,605 panelists responded out of 4,045 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals.Â Â Â Moira Fagan, Research AssociateÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchSneha Gubbala, Research Analyst Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership
entry.summary: Most Americans feel positively toward NATO. Democrats remain more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. benefits from membership. The post 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war
entry.summary: 44% of Americans say the U.S. has a responsibility to aid in Ukraine's defense. But the partisan gap on this issue has grown. The post 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin
entry.summary: Half of Americans see Russia as an enemy of the U.S., down since last year. Views of Russia and Putin remain largely negative. The post 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War
entry.summary: Republicans are less likely than last year to say Russia is an enemy and to say the U.S. has a responsibility to help Ukraine defend itself. The post Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S.
entry.summary: Americans tend to say U.S.-China trade benefits China more, though theyâ€™re skeptical that increased tariffs on China will be good for themselves or the U.S. The post 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of Chinaâ€™s role in the world
entry.summary: Most Americans say Chinaâ€™s global influence is growing stronger. Still, they tend to see the U.S. as the worldâ€™s top economic and military power. The post 2. Views of Chinaâ€™s role in the world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. U.S. views of China and Xi
entry.summary: Americans hold largely negative opinions of China and Xi Jinping, but ratings of both have improved slightly since 2024. The post 1. U.S. views of China and Xi appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans
entry.summary: Americans see China unfavorably, but the share with this view has dropped for the first time in five years. The post Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: âœš Breaking Out of Chart Software Defaults
entry.summary: Defaults are good for quick and disposable charts. However, when the audience extends beyond yourself, it's time to customize around purpose. Tags: default, editing, highlight

entry.title: Record hunger in Haiti amid rising needs
entry.summary: Escalating armed violence, displacement, economic turmoil and disruptions to local food production are fueling hunger in Haiti and leaving millions at risk, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: No respite for civilians amid unrelenting war and aid access barriers
entry.summary: As Sudanâ€™s civil war grinds on, millions of civilians remain trapped in a relentless cycle of displacement, hunger and violence, while relief efforts are stifled by insecurity and bureaucratic hurdles.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Libyaâ€™s fragile transition plagued by deepening economic and political divides
entry.summary: Libyaâ€™s prolonged political transition is facing renewed strain, with mounting economic pressures and tensions between rival governments threatening the calm that has held since the 2020 ceasefire.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights among new entries to UNESCO Memory of the World Register
entry.summary: The archives of British naturalist Charles Darwin, whose theory of evolution by natural selection revolutionized understanding of nature and humanityâ€™s place within it, are among 74 new additions to a UN list of documentary heritage of universal value.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Rise in violence against civilians in South Sudan
entry.summary: The number of civilians in South Sudan harmed by conventional parties to the conflict and other armed groups increased by 51 per cent in 2024, the UN Mission in the country (UNMISS) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Alongside conflict, an information war is still happening, warns UNRWA chief
entry.summary: Amid reported Israeli strikes across the Gaza Strip into Thursday that killed at least 23 people, the head of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, issued an urgent call to â€œget international media into Gazaâ€ to cover the conflict, in addition to those reporters trapped in the enclave.

entry.title: These are the 10 most popular national parks
entry.summary:
Since the U.S. National Park Service (NPS) started keeping records in 1904, its mountain landscapes, seaside wildernesses, and high desert acres have registered more than 16.4 billion visits. Some of the best-known parks experienced record crowds in 2024. Straddling the border between North Carolina and Tennessee, Great Smoky Mountains National Park passed 12 million recreation visits; almost 3.2 million people took in the massive U-shaped valleys and hulking granite peaks carved by ice flows long ago at Montana's Glacier National Park.
Visitors are drawn to the vastness and variety of â€œAmericaâ€™s best idea.â€ From sea to shining sea (as well as in the wilds of Alaska and Hawaii), the NPSâ€™s 85 million acres encompass 150,000 miles of rivers and streams and over 21,000 miles of trails.Â â€¦

entry.title: How to see the northern lightsâ€”and why theyâ€™re more common now
entry.summary:
The northern lights, or aurora borealis, hang above the fishing village of Reine on Norway's Lofoten archipelago. The best places to see this ethereal display are in "auroral zones" that are close to Earth's polesâ€”but sometimes you can see them from even farther north and south.

The aurora borealis and aurora australis have dazzled us in the night sky for centuries. Hereâ€™s what causes themâ€”and where the best places are to catch a glimpse. No matter how many times you see them, the northern lights, or aurora borealisâ€”and their Southern Hemisphere equivalent, the aurora australisâ€”are an ethereal, breathtaking sight. Dancing silently in Earthâ€™s upper atmosphere, they form iridescent sheets of green and red (or sometimes blue and purple) â€¦

entry.title: Is there really a secret city under the pyramids?
Running pros and eye experts say these are the best running sunglasses
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Hang out at a track or scroll through photos of a running event, and youâ€™ll notice that many runners donâ€™t wear sunglasses. But they should. Eye experts consistently advise wearing sunglasses whenever youâ€™re outside to decrease the risk of eye damage and diseases.Â
Quality running sunglasses should be lightweight, so you feel like youâ€™re not even wearing them. They should fit snugly, so they donâ€™t bounce as you move. They should also have sweat-resâ€¦

entry.title: How dragons lost their wicked menaceâ€”and became our friends
entry.summary:
â€œI desired dragons with a profound desire,â€ fantasy writer J.R.R. Tolkien once said about his childhood imagination, captivated as he wasÂ with the creatures of myth. That desire shaped his work for the rest of his life, and Tolkienâ€™s Smaug, the great fire breathing villain of The Hobbit,Â has loomed large in our cultural imaginations, but he was far from alone in his fascination. Â
Cultures around the world told stories about enormous, powerful, serpent-like creatures for centuries. From Mesopotamia to China and ancient Greece, the dragon has slithered alongside humanity, its lore ever-evolving, though many of the tropes are familiar even today: It crouches in caves on piles of gold, reeking of brimstone, waiting for intrepid heroes, or they take to the air, an ominous shadow that passâ€¦

entry.title: What is Good Fridayâ€”and whatâ€™s the meaning behind its name?
entry.summary:
For billions of Christians, Good Friday remains one of the holiest days in the religious calendar. Commemorating the day Jesus died by crucifixion around A.D. 30., Good Friday is a crucial part of the Christian Holy Week, the series of holidays that culminates in Easter, when, according to Christian faith, Jesus returned to life after dying on the cross.Â
Whatâ€™s the context behind Good Fridayâ€”and how do Christians observe it every year?Â Â
Good Friday represents Jesusâ€™ execution at the hands of the Romans. So why do Christians call the holiday â€œgoodâ€?Â
â€œâ€˜Goodâ€™ in this instance means something like â€˜holyâ€™ or â€˜pious.â€™ It is â€˜goodâ€™ because it is â€˜holy,â€™ not because we are supposed to think that crucifixion is a good thing,â€ explainsÂ Candida Moss, Edward Cadbury Professor of Thâ€¦

entry.title: Mary Magdalene probably wasnâ€™t a prostitute. Was she rich?
entry.summary:
This piece is adapted from the second edition of In The Footsteps of Jesus: A Chronicle of His Life and the Origins of Christianity.
Jesus may have traveled to the town that Matthew refers to as Magadan, which could mean Magdala (in fact, certain Greek manuscripts actually use the word â€œMagdalaâ€). Magdala was a major processing center of the Galilean fishing industry. Among others, it was renowned throughout the region for its fish sauce, a popular condiment in Antiquity.
One of Jesusâ€™ followers actually came from Magdala. Her name was Mary, â€œthe Magdalene,â€ but the Gospels give us very little information about her background. Unlike other women named â€œMaryâ€ in the Gospels, Mary Magdalene appears to be unattached, which was unusual. As scholars K. C. Hanson and Douglas Oakman havâ€¦

entry.title: How one divisive herb became an essential part of Thai cooking
entry.summary:
Blue Elephantâ€™s tom yum goong soup is flavoured with coriander root and garnished with the leaves. This grassy herb is one of the worldâ€™s most divisive, but in Thailand itâ€™s an integral part of the cuisine.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s the middle of dinner service at Bo.lan restaurant in Bangkok and our table for two is packed with all the dishes that make up a traditional Thai meal: salad, a laab of minced grey mullet that smells like nutty, toasted rice kernels; curry, a Southern-style chicken-and-prawn version made creamy with cashew nuts; a protein dish â€” stir-fried beef in a sauce thickened with shrimp paste; and much more besides.
I take a bite of stir-fried jÃ­cama (a turnip-like root vegetable) and dried prawns, garlandedâ€¦
